and yeah that's what I think too. It was clearly and intimate relationship, regardless if romance was involved. But with that level of intimacy, it raises questions. Sexuality is more fluid than just gay or straight often, so he very well could have a relationship with a man or woman and that wouldn't be unrealistic. From wikipedia:
Shipping, initially derived from the word relationship, is the desire by fans for two or more people, either real-life people or fictional characters (in film or literature) to be in a relationship, romantic or otherwise. It is considered a general term for fans' emotional involvement with the ongoing development of a relationship in a work of fiction. Shipping often takes the form of creative works, including fanfiction and fan art, most often published on the internet.
Shipping implies that it's just the fans wanting something that isn't there. In the BB universe, there are a lot of implications that Gus and Max were lovers. It's not just wishful thinking by the fandom. I'd say the problem with using "shipping" is that it has such a bad connotation.

That's just an ignorant comment. There's a lot of hinting at it, it's not shipping them, it has been implied in many ways.
1) Gus is a highly reasonable and rational man. This kind of vengeance doesn't seem characteristic even for a close friend of his.
2) He clearly has an intimate relationship with Max. In BB, Gus is very nervous about their plan, but Max calms him down and assures him that it will be fine. Gus paid for Max's education entirely.
3) Even in BB, Hector was mocking Gus as being gay. It could just be Hector being a piece of shit but he doesn't seem to do that to anyone else besides Max and Gus. In this last episode he made the "Butt brothers" comment which to me is proof that he believes Gus is actually gay. Doesn't mean he is, but at least Hector thinks so.
4) Gilligan will not confirm nor deny that they had a relationship. Doesn't necessarily mean that Gus and Max were gay, but it shows that it's at least ambiguous.
I'm not saying for sure Gus and Max were lovers, but saying that they're being "shipped" because many people suspect it is just plain ignorant. There is good reason to suspect it.
I guess that's true but it's just such a low effort karma grab. Very few of them are actually clever. Most are just a picture of a rock on the ground or a sunflower.

damn, no offense but you need to git gud! Keep fighting lynels and you should get to a point where you can reliably beat even the more difficult ones.
Here's some tips:
Shoot lynels in the face with a bow - it staggers them (stock up on arrows)
After shooting them, you can run around back and mount them - attacks from mounted don't degrade weapons
Practice dodging and parrying - absolutely necessary to beat lynels
Other than that upgrade your armor, get stronger weapons, and stock up on meals.

sommer

Why do I need to answer how to fix it? I don't know exactly how we combat it. That's why there are people across disciplines who study this kind of stuff and try to create social change. I'm studying computer science. I am not a sociologist. Arguing whether or not affirmative action is wrong and arguing what should be done instead of affirmative action are two different debates.
However, it's simple to me that affirmative action is wrong for the same reasons that discriminating against minorities is wrong. Logically if you are opposed to white people being favored and minorities being hurt by discrimination, on the premise that a person should not be discriminated against or favored based on race/ethnicity/gender/etc., then you should be opposed to affirmative action, since it is exactly that; discrimination based on race/ethnicity/gender/etc. Am I saying that affirmative action does no good at all or doesn't help minorities sometimes? No, but the ends don't justify the means, and I'd also say it's a problem if when does affirmative action stop? At what point can we say "okay, everyone seems to be on a level playing field, so we don't need affirmative action"? I don't see that happening.
Conjecture

1) I'm talking about both, and way to add some new things into your original response without putting an edit
2) I'll concede that there aren't enough protections but I stand by my point that it's either not legal or not socially acceptable
POLITICZ
You cannot legally give a family member a job in a company, unless its a family owned business.

It is bad, and I don't know the answer exactly how to combat this. That's a different debate. Two wrongs do not make a right. Affirmative action is wrong, as is discrimination.
Edit: also, if companies are refusing to hire qualified employees because of their race/ethnicity, then they are losing out on good employees and another company that doesn't discriminate will hire them and benefit. The free market only cares about money. Those who choose to discriminate will lose out.

Because those things are not socially acceptable and some not even legal. Still happens, but you won't find many people who will argue that nepotism is morally permissible. Personally I do know many people, including myself who think it's completely unfair for athletes to get into schools just because they are talented athletes, even though their grades are terrible. And as far as wealth giving you a better chance at getting accepted into a school or into a job, I'm not sure that is acceptable to anyone. I don't know that it happens all the time either.
Connections shouldn't mean lowered standards and if it does, that's clearly wrong. Networking is the way people get jobs. That's just how it happens. I think everyone has seen instances of an under qualified person getting a job simply due to connections, but as I said it's not socially or maybe even legally acceptable to do that.
Edit: my point is that these aren't socially acceptable and/or legally acceptable whereas affirmative action is supported heavily in law and in society

I agree with you that most people argue out of selfishness and don't actually care about principles when it comes to affirmative action, they only claim it when it suits their agenda. However, blindly supporting affirmative action because "if you don't you're racist" is stupid too. A lot of people do that because either they are minorities and it benefits them or it's because they want to score some minority points and look like the good guys. Affirmative action is a real moral issue. In my opinion, it is wrong to discriminate race/ethnicity/gender etc. when hiring or accepting into college. The only exceptions would be when it actually pertains to the job (e.g. hiring only an Indian actor to play the role of Ghandi in a film). It shouldn't matter if the ones benefitting from the discrimination are minorities. Discrimination is wrong regardless of who benefits and who is negatively affected.

I still think affirmative action is morally wrong. Race/ethnicity should never be a deciding factor in who gets a job or who gets accepted into school. It's also a stain for minorities who legitimately were the best candidates, because there will always be the question of whether or not affirmative action had something to do with it. I'm sure this girl is one that never needed affirmative action, and it's a shame that it would even be discussed in her situation.
